intro: Porophyllum tagetoides, commonly known as Mexican daisy, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies, sunflowers, and other composite flowers. The plant features showy yellow flowers surrounded by white ray florets, and it has a basal rosette of hairy, gray-green leaves. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Porophyllum tagetoides is drought-tolerant and is often used in xeriscaping due to its hardy nature.
